Award.AwardTitle: Meeting: 2nd International Symposium on Ranaviruses, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN, July 27 - 29, 2013
Award.AbstractNarration: Ranaviruses (family Iridoviridae) are increasingly recognized as global threats to ecologically and commercially important fish, reptiles, and amphibians. For example, one ranavirus, Singapore grouper iridovirus, has triggered substantial losses among mariculture facilities in Asia, whereas Frog virus 3 (FV3)-like viruses have contributed to die-offs among both wild and cultured frogs and turtles throughout the world. To understand the impacts of these emerging infections among cold-blooded vertebrates, the 2nd International Symposium on Ranaviruses (ISR) will focus on ranavirus-mediated disease at the ecological, molecular, immunological, and pathological levels. The meeting will bring together senior and junior investigators, as well as post-doctoral fellows and graduate students, with complementary skill sets in an effort to understand how viral, host, and environmental factors interact to produce the observed ecological, pathological, and population phenotypes and to develop novel diagnostic protocols and control measures. In addition to platform and poster presentations, the 2nd ISR will host two field trips to provide professionals with the tools needed to sample and identify ranavirus-infected animals. Moreover, by coupling the 2nd ISR with the annual International Conference of the Wildlife Disease Association (WDA), information related to ranaviral disease and its impact on cold-blooded vertebrates can be communicated to a larger audience through participation in both meetings and a plenary presentation at the WDA Conference summarizing key findings from the 2nd ISR. Collectively, by bringing together virologists, immunologists, ecologists, and veterinarians, the 2nd ISR will provide a forum for better understanding ranaviruses and provide an extremely effective way to bring together individuals with diverse skills in an effort to understand and control an emerging threat to cold-blooded vertebrates within both the natural environment and commercial aquaculture-based enterprises.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2nd International Symposium on Ranaviruses (2nd ISR) was held July 27 & 28, 2013 in Knoxville, TN.  The meeting brought together both senior and junior investigators as well as graduate students to examine the impact of ranaviruses on various species of cold-blooded vertebrates.  Extensive study over the last 30 years has shown that these agents are important pathogens of fish, amphibians, and reptiles.  Ranaviruses have caused life-threatening systemic infections accompanied by high mortality in ecologically-important amphibians and commercially-important fish. Given the increasing importance of aquaculture and mariculture, ranaviruses poise real and potential threats to animal health.  To address the challenge provided by ranavirus infections, 54 scientists, 34 from the USA and 20 from the remainder of the world, attended the meeting and discussed their work in 35 oral and 35 poster presentations.  The participants learned about current studies involving ranavirus replication, taxonomy, anti-viral immune responses, diagnostic methods, and the impact of ranaviruses on populations of ectothermic vertebrates.  The meeting resulted in a better understanding of ranaviruses, the diseases they cause, the diagnosis of ranavirus disease, and the development of vaccines and treatments to limit their adverse impacts.  Two field trips provided hands-on experience in viral surveillance and health assessments.  The results of this meeting have been disseminated in a number of ways.  The website for the Global Ranavirus Consortium provides contact information and video clips of all talks presented at the 2011 and 2013 meetings as well as references related to ranavirus research.  In addition, Drs. Gray and Chinchar are serving as co-editors of an e-book (publication anticipated in the Fall of 2014) detailing the latest research on ranavirus biology, anti-viral immunity, ecology, pathology, and diagnosis.  Drs. Chinchar and Waltzek recently summarized the state of ranavirus research in a PLoS Pathogens Pearl (“Ranaviruses: Not just for frogs,” PLoS Pathogens 10:e1003850, 2014), and a summary of the 2nd ISR was presented to the annual meeting of the Wildlife Disease Association by VG Chinchar on July 29, 2013.   Lastly it is anticipated that many of the talks and posters presented at this meeting will serve as the basis for full-length scientific manuscripts detailing various aspects of ranavirus biology and disease.
